channel.title: Motorcycles
channel.description:
Motorcycles have and always will be a huge part of my life, I mainly opened this thread to open a discussion motorcycles since there isn't an active one over on this board.
Below is a small history of my motorcycle career;
2001 - Started racing in the "Junior A" class of the scottish minimoto championship. 2002 - Placed 3rd in the Junior A class of the scottish minimoto championship at the mere age of 7. 2003 - Made my first sponsorship from AJPerformance for a small 20% discount at their store, however, it was a start. 2004 - Won the Junior B class of the scottish minimoto championship at 9 years old. 2006 - Won the Junior C class and placed 2nd in the "Supers" or top class at age 11. 2007 - Started racing my RS125 in the big boy class as I call it, the KDMC sottish 125cc championship, placed 7th out of 21 racers, which for a novice or orange bib, is pretty good. 2008 - Placed 2nd in the RS125 class, at the mere age of 13. This was only me coming out of my novice season. 2009 - Won the RS125 class and started riding my R6 in my spare time, track days etc. 2010 - Became Yamaha's youngest sponsored rider in Scotland. Thus making me Semi-Professional. I also started training seriously training on their Yz125's and such. 2011 - Was placing 1st in the first 11 races of our championship on the R6, had a major crash during the second race of our 6th meeting after leading by 32 seconds from riders over three times my age and experience. I crushed the entire right hand side of my body. I also done a wildcard in the european superstock 600 championship. This made an end to my racing career in this year. 2012 - I've done a lot of testing for Yamaha and done a few wildcard races, I'm nothing compared to what I used to be though, I just don't have the physical endurance anymore due to the crash.
As of 2012, I am just a test and demonstration rider for Yamaha. They fly me over the world when they need someone to make a statement. I just generally show the bike off, then I take my helmet off and have the cameras on me, they see how young I am and everyone is wowed. It's pretty good being me, I suppose.
So what's your bikes/racing history?

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @ranger_squad ranger squad
item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:75, topic:455688”][quote author=ranger squad link=topic=558601.msg4096187#msg4096187 date=1346870896]

Honestly, I’ve never been near a bike, so I don’t know what goes on. But I do respect the people who build the bikes from ground up.

Building the engine from scratch is pretty close to impossible.
[/quote]

Not necessarily. If you have the correct tools/moulds for the hot forming process and then tempering, you’d be able to do it. With no other tools than vernier calipers and a spanner set.[/quote]

For your average person

Building the engine from scratch is pretty close to impossible.[/quote]

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @ranger_squad ranger squad
item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:69, topic:455688”]

You can build them from the ground up from a frame as well. This is my personal favorite custom chopper. Built by Paul Jr. back when he was still with OCC. There is so much customization you can do to a motorcycle if you can think outside the box. Of course some not all things are road legal or safe so you need to watch what your doing ;)[/quote]
The white bike above, that my dads making, is from the ground up

Read full topic

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

Customisation on a bike is as endless as it is on a car. It can range from new mirrors, to new radiator covers, back to a different swingarm, a custom numberplate(width and height), different indicators, new handlebars, different engine… the list goes on and on, down to the really small stuff such as different footpegs.

If you’ve raced at the level I have, you’ll realise that EVERY single little detail that can take .002 of a second from your laptime has and will be done.

Read full topic

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @ranger_squad ranger squad
item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:67, topic:455688”]NOBODY FREAK THE HELL OUT AND START FLAMING. was just my personal opinion, prove to me what else you could customize on a bike (chopper or a motorcycle). i’ve also never liked bikes cause their so freaking loud, it’s stupid.

but think about it, what else can you do to a bike other than a custom paint job, making it louder (muffler tips), bigger wheels, neon lights, and modifying the engine. i can’t think of anything else, but that’s just me.[/quote]

Custom swingarm, custom yokes, custom forks, custom frame, custom bodywork…

My dad’s currently building a motorbike (making some parts himself out of aluminium, and buying others) and here are some pictures:



As to what other people can customise:




I’d choose a loud bike over a loud car anyday.

Read full topic

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @ranger_squad ranger squad
item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:56, topic:455688”][quote author=Niall link=topic=558601.msg4093995#msg4093995 date=1346669725]

I’ve been only doing 60 before and people pull out in front of me and I have to go around them because I have no time to slow down.

so don’t drive in people’s blindspots?

Problem is people don’t really pay attention. As any motorcycle driver knows the risk is not yourself, its other drivers.[/quote]

so again, don’t drive in people’s blindspots? if you’re in front of them or behind them they’d have to go out of their way to hit you especially if you’re driving in the centre of your lane, them not paying attention isn’t an excuse for you to not drive defensively

There is only so much you can do when your going 60 and someone pulls out about 15 yards in front of you.

don’t make me repeat myself again

ever hear of the 2 second rule? here’s a hint, you can also choose to apply it to people in surrounding lanes ! shocking I know

Pulling out infront of me does not mean he was already there. That means he pulls out from another road or driveway. Call me an idiotic driver if you want but I drive responsibly when there are other vehicles. Do I need to make a damn reference picture to describe what I am talking about?[/quote]

please coonie

Read full topic

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:

CoonHunter:

Pulling out infront of me does not mean he was already there. That means he pulls out from another road or driveway. Call me an idiotic driver if you want but I drive responsibly when there are other vehicles. Do I need to make a damn reference picture to describe what I am talking about?

so you’re doing 60 on residential roads and/or where cars can pull out on you? I assumed we were talking about motorways, not pissing residential areas

WHICH MAKES IT EVEN WORSE aaaaaaaaa

Read full topic
